Box 107, Gajeongro 141, Yuseong Daejeon 34113 Republic of Korea Graphical abstract The design of efficient zeolite-supported Co catalysts is essential for the further development of the one-step production of liquid fuels via the low-temperature Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS). Herein, Co/zeolite catalysts were prepared from zeolites SSZ-13, ZSM-22, ZSM-11, ZSM-5, Mordenite, and Y. Their textural and acidic properties, Co dispersion, and internal diffusion behaviors were comprehensively analyzed, along with their FTS product mixtures. Counterintuitively, the degree of isomerization and hydrocarbon decomposition did not correlate with the acidic properties of the zeolite support. Instead, catalysts with high characteristic diffusivity delivered product mixtures with high degree of isomerization and decomposition, suggesting that the access of paraffinic hydrocarbons to the internal acid sites of the zeolite determines the upgrading performance of the bifunctional Co/zeolite catalyst in the low-temperature FTS reaction. Hence, the present findings support upcoming efforts on the design of new and effective FTS catalysts. Keywords Fischer–Tropsch Bifunctional catalysts Cobalt Zeolite Hydrocarbon upgrading 1 Introduction The conversion of syngas, produced by the steam reforming of natural gas or gasification of coal and biomass, can replace most of the conventional petroleum-based products [1–5]. Diesel fuels obtained by the low-temperature Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) are essentially sulfur-free and their combustion emits less air pollutants such as NOx, particulate matter, and total hydrocarbons than that of conventional fuels. Hence, the interest in their use as alternative fuels is rapidly growing [6,7]. The general low-temperature FTS follows the Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) model, yielding mainly normal paraffins (n-paraffins) with a wide range of chain lengths [8]. Although these paraffinic hydrocarbon mixtures have high cetane number, their direct use as diesel fuels is limited by their low liquidity [9]. Therefore, additional upgrading processes such as cracking and isomerization are required to obtain diesel fuels suitable for use over a wide temperature range [10,11]. An attractive approach to shorten the multi-step process of the conventional FTS is the direct synthesis of high-fluidity fuels from syngas using hybrid catalysts in a single reactor [12–16], including efforts to produce the desired liquid products using Co/zeolite hybrid catalysts [16–19]. In addition to the acidic properties of zeolites, their high porosity, shape-selectivity, and transport properties render them suitable catalyst supports for this complex reaction. In zeolite-supported Co catalytic systems, metallic Co catalyzes the syngas conversion to long-chain hydrocarbons, which undergo secondary reactions such as oligomerization, isomerization, and cracking at the acid sites of the zeolite. Thus, the final product selectivity largely depends on the physicochemical characteristics of the zeolite. Consequently, many studies have focused on controlling the liquid product distribution by varying the zeolite properties [18,20]. In general, the use of zeolites as support materials led to the predominant formation of lighter hydrocarbons and increase in the isoparaffin selectivity as a result of cracking and isomerization, respectively [21–24]. For instance, the ZSM-5-supported Co catalyst showed high selectivity for gasoline-range hydrocarbons due to the unique pore structure and appropriate amount and strength of the acid sites of ZSM-5, which has a low Si/Al ratio [25]. Moreover, the introduction of mesoporosity in the zeolite support increased the CO conversion and degree of isomerization owing to the increase in the Co dispersion and acidity regulation [21,26,27]. However, most of these studies have been made using a single zeolite and no insights were obtained from systematic studies correlating the structures of various zeolite to FTS performance. Decades ago, Bessell investigated the effect of the zeolite type (ZSM-5, ZSM-11, ZSM-12, and ZSM-34) in the Co/zeolite bifunctional catalyst on the chain length and n-alkane content of the hydrocarbon products [28]. Contrary to the general expectations, this study revealed that lighter hydrocarbons were obtained as the zeolite acidity decreased. Furthermore, the secondary reaction appeared to be facilitated by a zeolite with a large channel size, indicating that the accessibility to the internal acid sites is more important than the acid strength and amount of acid sites for the secondary transformations of hydrocarbons. However, the crucial factors that correlate the product distribution to the topological structure of zeolite have been scarcely studied to date. Herein, six different types of zeolite, namely SSZ-13, ZSM-22, ZSM-11, ZSM-5, Mordenite, and Y, were used as support material in Co/zeolite bifunctional FTS catalysts. With the aim to maximize the yield of fluidic hydrocarbons, the Co dispersion, acidic characteristics, and internal diffusion of hydrocarbons were comprehensively studied. In-depth analysis of the product mixtures was performed to identify the correlation between the abovementioned catalyst characteristics and the hydrocarbon distribution. This contribution may shed light on establishing the criteria when selecting material for Co/zeolite bifunctional FTS catalyst. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation ZSM-5, Y, and Mordenite were purchased from Zeolyst. ZSM-11 and ZSM-22 were purchased from Vision Chemicals. SSZ-13 was purchased from ACS Material. All zeolites were calcined at 823 K for 6 h to obtain H+-form zeolites. Co was deposited on the zeolites by incipient wetness impregnation using an aqueous Co(NO3)2∙6H2O solution (Samchun Chemicals, 97 %). After impregnation, the sample was dried at 383 K overnight and calcined at 773 K for 5 h in dry air. The Co loading was 10 wt% for all catalysts. 2.2 FTS procedure and evaluation The FTS reaction was conducted in a fixed-bed reactor (9.5 mm internal diameter). In a typical experiment, 0.4 g of catalyst (20–30 mesh) was mixed with 1.2 g of α-Al2O3. The prepared catalyst bed was loaded in the middle of the reactor. Prior to reaction, the catalyst was reduced with 5 % H2/Ar gas (0.1 MPa) at 673 K for 7 h. The reactor was cooled to 453 K and filled with He. The system was gradually pressurized to 2 MPa and the temperature was increased to 513 K under He flow. The feed gas was switched to premixed syngas (H2/CO = 2) with 10 % Ar as an internal standard. The reaction was conducted at 513 K, 2 MPa, and 4000 mL h−1∙gcat −1. The gaseous products were analyzed online using a YL6100 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). H2, CO, CO2, and CH4 were separated on a Carboxene 1000 column and analyzed using TCD. Gaseous C1–C4 hydrocarbons were separated on a GasPro column and analyzed using FID under He flow. After 45 h, the liquid products were collected in a hot trap (353 K) and analyzed offline using a Leco GC × GC-FID (2D-GC) equipped with an Agilent 7890B GC system. The CO conversion, CO2 selectivity, and individual hydrocarbon selectivity in total hydrocarbons were calculated by Eqs. 1–5: (1) C O c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = C O , i n - C O , o u t C O , i n × 100 (2) C O 2 s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = C O 2 , o u t C O , i n - C O , o u t × 100 (3) C H 4 s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = C H 4 , o u t C O , i n - C O , o u t × 100 (4) C i ( i = 2 , 3 o r 4 ) s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = C i , o u t C O , i n - C O , o u t × 100 (5) C5+ selectivity (%) = 100 % − (SCO2 + SCH4 + SC2 + SC3 + SC4) The formation of hydrocarbons in the FTS follows the ASF distribution, which is expressed by eq. 6: [8] (6) W n n = ( 1 - α ) 2 α n - 1 where Wn is the weight fraction of a hydrocarbon with chain length n and α is the chain growth probability. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter were calculated from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms obtained at liquid N2 temperature using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 system. Prior to the adsorption measurements, all samples were vacuum-degassed at 573 K for 4 h. The pore size distributions of the samples were calculated using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda model. Temperature-programmed NH3 desorption (NH3-TPD) measurements were carried out on an Autochem Ⅱ 2920 instrument (Micromeritics). The samples were first pretreated at 873 K under a He flow for 1 h, cooled down to 373 K, and exposed to 15 % NH3/He for 30 min. Subsequently, the samples were purged with He to remove physically absorbed NH3 from their surface. Finally, NH3 desorption was performed at a heating rate of 10 K/min up to 873 K under flow of He. The adsorption of n-hexane (Sigma-Aldrich, 99 %) on the catalysts was measured using a modified thermogravimetric analysis method (TGA N-1000, Thermo Co.; Figure S1). In each case, 10 mg of the sample was degassed at 823 K for 1 h and cooled down to 379 K under He flow. Subsequently, n-hexane-saturated He gas (298 K) was fed into the sample (373 K). The mass increase was recorded as a function of time and the diffusion kinetics was calculated based on Fick’s second law of diffusion (Eq. 7): (7) ∂ C ∂ t = D ( ∂ 2 C ∂ x 2 ) Under the assumption of a slab-like zeolite, Eq. 8 can be applied: [29] (8) q ( t ) q ( ∞ ) = 2 π D L 2 t where q ( t ) / q ( ∞ ) is the normalized uptake, D is the diffusivity, L is the characteristic diffusion path length, and t is the time. H2 chemisorption and O2 titration on catalysts were measured (ASAP 2020 system, Micromeritics). Prior to the measurements, the samples were degassed at 473 K for 4 h under vacuum and reduced with H2 at 673 K for 1 h. The cell containing the catalyst was evacuated (673 K, 1 h) and cooled down to 373 K. The H2 adsorption was measured using TCD at 373 K under H2 flow. Subsequently, the catalyst was heated to 673 K at a rate of 10 K/min under He flow. Next, O2 titration was carried out at 673 K to determine the reduction degree of the catalyst. The Co dispersion was calculated assuming a 1:1 H/Co stoichiometry. The number of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites (BAS and LAS, respectively) on the catalyst surface was calculated using Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) after adsorption of probe molecules. Pyridine (Py) was used to measure the total number of BAS and LAS on the internal pore walls and external surfaces of the catalysts, whereas the larger derivative 2,6-di-tert-butylpyridine (DTBPy) was used to determine the number of external acid sites. FT-IR spectra were acquired on a Thermo Nicolet Nexus 4700 instrument equipped with a HgCdTe-B detector. Prior to the analysis, a self-supporting disk (12 mm diameter) was placed in the transparent cell, which was evacuated (723 K, 4 h). Subsequently, the adsorption of probe molecules was carried out at 423 K for 1 h. Weakly adsorbed molecules were removed at the same temperature for 2 h. BAS and LAS were quantified using the integrated absorbances of the IR bands at 1545 and 1455 cm−1, respectively [30]. Molar extinction coefficients of 1.13 and 1.28 cm/μmol were used for the BAS and LAS, respectively, according to Guisnet et al. The concentration of external BAS was calculated assuming that the extinction coefficient of DTBPy at 1616 cm-1 is 10.1 cm/μmol [31]. The particle size of the zeolite samples was analyzed using a laser diffraction instrument (Microtrac). The zeolites were dispersed in ethanol prior to measurement. The mean particle diameter was defined using the particle size distribution curve obtained in the range of 0.01–2000 μm. Previous works displayed that mean particle size obtained from particle size analyzer is consistent with crystal size from the scanning electron microscopy or transmission electron microscopy images [32,33]. The histograms of results were shown in Figure S5. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characteristics The pore size and channel structure of the studied zeolites are summarized in Table S1. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the H+-exchanged zeolites and Co-impregnated catalysts are shown in Figure S2 and the corresponding textural properties are summarized in Table 1 . Among the six typical adsorption isotherm types [34,35], only type Ⅰ and Ⅳ isotherms were observed in the present work. With the exception of Y, all zeolites presented type Ⅰ isotherms, which are characteristic of microporous materials with a relatively small external specific surface area [34]. These zeolites exhibited a sharp uptake at P/P0<0.01 associated with micropore filling and H4 type hysteresis loops that correspond to limited amounts of mesopores [35]. Y zeolite displayed a type Ⅳ isotherm, representing mesoporous characteristics and capillary condensation in the mesopores at P/P0>0.42. The deposition of Co on the zeolites led to a decrease in the surface area and pore volume but did not affect the isotherm shape, suggesting that Co particles deposited on the external surface of the zeolite blocked the micropore mouth without altering the skeletal pore structure. The pore blocking effect was most significant in Co/SSZ-13. As this zeolite has the smallest pore size among the studied samples, its pores are most easily blocked by Co particles. Consequently, a decrease in surface area and micropore volume of 56 % and 57 %, respectively, was observed. The decrease in surface area and micropore volume of ZSM-22 and Mordenite was also noticeable, presumably due to the one-dimensional transport channels in their pore structure. Unlike three-dimensional channel structures, blocking of the pore mouth of a one-way channel prevents gas diffusion, thus leading to a larger decrease in the pore volume. The acidic characteristics of the catalysts were investigated by using NH3-TPD and FT-IR with Py as a probe molecule (Py-IR). The NH3-TPD curves of the samples show three distinct peaks associated with weak, medium, and strong (approximately 190, 280, and 400 ℃, respectively) acid sites (Fig. 1 (a)). The corresponding deconvolution results are summarized in Table 2 . As expected, the total amount of acid sites decreased with the Si/Al ratio (Figure S3) [36]. In the Py-IR spectra (Fig. 1(b)), the adsorption bands at 1545 and 1450 cm−1 were assigned to pyridinium ions formed at BAS and to Py adsorbed at coordinatively unsaturated Al3+ LAS, respectively [30]. To confirm that the peaks appeared indeed come from the acid sites of the zeolite, Co/SiO2 was additionally synthesized and Py-IR was taken under same condition used for Co/zeolite catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1(b), no Py adsorption bands were observed for for Co/SiO2, indicating that the Py adsorption peaks come from zeolite acid site not the metallic Co. The quantification of acid sites of Co/zeolite catalysts by Py-IR is summarized in Table 2. In general, the total amount of acid sites calculated from NH3-TPD and Py-IR was similar. However, the strength and type of acid sites are not necessarily correlated [37]. For instance, Co/ZSM-5 and Co/Y have the same Si/Al ratio, but the former had more strong acid sites and less LAS than Co/Y. Additionally, the concentration of external acid sites was determined by FT-IR using DTBPy as a probe molecule (DTBPy-IR; Fig. 1(c)) [31]. Co/SSZ-13 and Co/ZSM-11 exhibited the characteristic DTBPyH+ ion band at 1616 cm−1, albeit with lower intensities than those previously observed for the PyH+ ion. Moreover, the distinct absorbance at 1616 cm−1 was not observed in the spectra of the other catalysts, suggesting that the external acid sites of most zeolites disappeared during Co impregnation. The well-documented decrease in the acid sites by metal addition is due to the exchange of acidic protons with metal precursors [27,38–40]. The dispersion and mean particle size of Co was calculated by H2 chemisorption followed by O2 titration (Table S2). Generally, the Co particle sizes decreased with the increase in the external surface area (Figure S4) and did not correlate with the micropore size or structure, supporting our hypothesis that the Co particles are present mainly on the external surface of the zeolites. The reduction degree of Co particles can be influenced by various factors but the metal-support interaction is known to mainly contribute [41]. That is, the strong metal-support interaction tends to hinder the Co reduction. If all the zeolite supports tested in the present study have similar external surface area, the Co particle size will be only determined by the metal-support interaction and the reducibility will be inverse proportional to the Co particle size. However, the high external surface area provide sufficient space for Co to be well dispersed, resulting in small-sized Co particles. Thus, the Co particle size does not directly describe the metal-support interaction and reducibility. We found that the Co particle size tended to decrease with external surface area but the small Co particle size does not necessarily make the reduction difficult. To investigate the effect of the intracrystalline structure of the zeolite on the diffusion behavior, the n-hexane adsorption kinetics was studied. We used n-hexane (4.3 Å kinetic diameter) as a model adsorbate that can permeate all catalysts except for SSZ-13 (3.7 Å pore diameter). Fig. 2 shows the normalized n-hexane uptake of the catalysts as a function of the adsorption time. The characteristic diffusivity values (D/L 2) obtained from Eq. 8 are summarized in Table S3. As expected from its pore size, the n-hexane uptake of Co/SSZ-13 was negligible (lowest diffusion kinetics). Regarding the other catalysts, the n-hexane adsorption was not solely dependent on the pore size. Although Co/Y has the largest pore size, its diffusivity (D/L 2 = 0.00342) was smaller than those of Co/ZSM-11 (0.00908), Co/ZSM-5 (0.00479), and Co/ZSM-22 (0.00448), indicating that the channel structure or chemical composition of the zeolite can also affect the diffusion behavior [42]. 3.2 Catalyst performance in the FTS The FTS performance of the Co/zeolite catalysts was evaluated over 40 h (Figure S6). The mean values of CO conversion and product selectivity were obtained between 10 and 20 h (Table 3 ). The proportion of isoparaffins (C iso) and olefins (C ole) in the liquid products were determined by 2D-GC, whereas the chain growth probabilities (α) were calculated from the liquid product distribution using Eq. 6. The 2D-GC analysis results are shown in Fig. 3 and the C iso, C ole, and α values are summarized in Table 3. We illustrate distributions above C10 in Fig. 3 because the hydrocarbons ranged between C5-C10 were expected to evaporate to a large extent through the liquid trap at temperature of 353 K. However, we note that such high temperature of trap enables accurate detection of gaseous hydrocarbons under C4. In our previous work [27], the Co/Al2O3 catalyst manly produced paraffinic hydrocarbons showing the (isoparaffin + olefin)/total hydrocarbon ratio in liquid products of 0.2 at the reaction temperature of 513 K [27]. Thus, the use of zeolite as a catalyst support used in the present study is responsible for the high degree of isomerization and cracking in the liquid products. The formations of isoparrraffin and olefin at the reaction temperature of 503−523 K by using zeolite supports were also reported elsewhere [18,43,44]. The highest CO conversion of 56.7 % was observed over Co/ZSM-5, followed by Co/ZSM-11 of 54.8 %. Co/ZSM-22 has the lowest activity. 2D-GC data (Fig. 3 (a)) showed that n-paraffin, isoparaffin and olefin are completely separated with negligible aromatic content. Co/ZSM-11 presented the highest isoparaffin and olefin content in the liquid product. Co/Mordenite displayed the highest C5+ selectivity, however most of liquid hydrocarbon were n-paraffins. The intrinsic activity of Co in the FTS was reported to increase with the Co particle size until the latter reaches a critical size of approximately 5 nm [45,46]. When the Co particle size was larger than the critical size, the intrinsic activity was maintained [45–47]. As all catalysts prepared in the present study have particle sizes of tens of nanometers (Table S2), the effect of particle size on the intrinsic activity is expected to be negligible. Fig. 4 (a) shows nearly constant turnover frequencies (TOFs) for the CO consumption over a wide range of Co particle sizes in the catalysts. Accordingly, Co/ZSM-5 and Co/ZSM-22 with the highest and lowest cobalt dispersion values exhibited the highest and lowest CO conversion, respectively. Moreover, both the CO conversion and the product selectivity are constant for particles larger than the critical size [47,48]. Our results corroborate this finding, as the prepared catalysts exhibited nearly constant CH4 and C5+ selectivities (Fig. 4(b)). These results indicate that the physicochemical properties of the support do not affect the reactions occurring on the Co surface. As the Co particles are deposited on the external surface of the zeolite, surface processes including adsorption of the reactants, chain growth, and desorption of long-chain hydrocarbons are not influenced by the acidity of the zeolite and reactant diffusion in the microporous structure. However, the acidity and diffusion characteristics of the zeolite play an important role in the isomerization and cracking of the long-chain hydrocarbons produced via the Co catalyzed surface reactions [49,50]. Hence, the variations in the composition of the liquid products (Fig. 3) is mainly determined by the properties of the zeolite. Therefore, we investigated the effect of zeolite acidity in the isomerization and cracking of the liquid hydrocarbon products. Accordingly, the proportion of isoparaffins (C iso) and the chain growth probability (α) were plotted against the acidic properties of the zeolites (Fig. 5 ), which were evaluated by NH3-TPD and Py-IR. Unexpectedly, the hydrocarbon isomerization and cracking seems to decrease with the increase in the total acid sites (Fig. 5(a)) [19], as C iso directly represents the isomerization degree of the liquid hydrocarbons and α is inversely proportional to the cracking activity [51,52]. However, a relationship between C iso and α and the sum of LASs and BASs is not apparent (Fig. 5(b)), and no clear correlation was observed between these values and the strength and type of the acid sites (Figure S8). Next, we plotted the C iso and α values against the characteristic diffusivity (D/L 2) of the catalysts (Fig. 6 ). Although deviations from linearity are observed in both plots, C iso and α appear to correlate more strongly with the diffusion properties than with the acid characteristics of the catalysts. Catalysts with faster n-hexane diffusion exhibited higher C iso and lower α values, suggesting that the liquid hydrocarbon isomerization and cracking were mainly promoted by the ready access of paraffins to the internal acid sites of the zeolites rather than the number or strength of the latter. This effect is schematically illustrated in Fig. 7 . Furthermore, it is notable that Co/SSZ-13 exhibited moderate isomerization and cracking activity despite its low characteristic diffusivity. This activity may be attributed to the existence of external acid sites that effect paraffin conversion (Fig. 1(c)). Therefore, the relationship between diffusion and isomerization/cracking is only applicable to catalysts that allow a sufficient extent of hydrocarbon transport through their zeolitic structure. A previous study suggested that the slow diffusion of hydrocarbons through the zeolite channels, and the consequently longer retention, leads to a decrease in the isoparaffin yield due to excessive hydrocracking [29]. However, this overcracking was not observed in the present study, even for zeolites with the slowest hydrocarbon diffusion rates. Presumably, this overreaction at the acid sites is prevented at low temperatures. As the CC bond scission that takes place on the acid sites results in the formation of olefinic hydrocarbons, the amount of olefins in the liquid hydrocarbons tended to increase with the decrease in the α value (Fig. 8 (a)). Furthermore, the olefin and isoparaffin contents are proportional (Fig. 8(b)), suggesting that cracking and isomerization occur to similar extents according to the diffusion characteristics of the zeolite. 4 Conclusions In the context of the one-step synthesis of liquid fuels, we investigated the effects of pore structure and acidic properties of the zeolites on the upgrading of long-chain hydrocarbons obtained by the FTS with Co/zeolite bifunctional catalysts prepared from six different types of zeolites. Since the Co particles were deposited on the external surface of the zeolites, the pore structure of the latter did not significantly affect the FTS catalytic performance of Co. Hence, the examined series of Co/zeolite catalysts exhibited constant TOFs and methane selectivities. However, diffusion of the long-chain hydrocarbons generated on the Co surface in the internal structure of the zeolite triggered secondary reactions such as isomerization and cracking. Regarding the extent of isomerization and cracking of the liquid hydrocarbons, while a relationship with the type or amount of acid sites in the catalyst remains elusive, a clear correlation was identified with the characteristic diffusivity values of the zeolites. Our results imply that the accessibility of reactant to the internal acid sites is more important than the acidic characteristics itself for isomerization and cracking. That is, the rapid diffusion of hydrocarbons into the micropore of the zeolite is a key factor for isomerization and cracking. Therefore, zeolites with a structural topology that allows high Co dispersion and fast hydrocarbon diffusion are crucial in the design of bifunctional catalysts for the efficient upgrading of synthetic fuels. coredata.dc:description: The design of efficient zeolite-supported Co catalysts is essential for the further development of the one-step production of liquid fuels via the low-temperature Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS). Herein, Co/zeolite catalysts were prepared from zeolites SSZ-13, ZSM-22, ZSM-11, ZSM-5, Mordenite, and Y. Their textural and acidic properties, Co dispersion, and internal diffusion behaviors were comprehensively analyzed, along with their FTS product mixtures. Counterintuitively, the degree of isomerization and hydrocarbon decomposition did not correlate with the acidic properties of the zeolite support. Instead, catalysts with high characteristic diffusivity delivered product mixtures with high degree of isomerization and decomposition, suggesting that the access of paraffinic hydrocarbons to the internal acid sites of the zeolite determines the upgrading performance of the bifunctional Co/zeolite catalyst in the low-temperature FTS reaction. Hence, the present findings support upcoming efforts on the design of new and effective FTS catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Diffusion-dependent upgrading of hydrocarbons synthesized by Co/zeolite bifunctional Fischer–Tropsch catalysts
